input.source:
Use `$$\begin{matrix}…\end{matrix}$$` In between the `\begin` and `\end`, put the matrix elements. End each matrix row with `\\`, and separate matrix elements with `&`. For example,
```
$$
    \begin{matrix}
    1 & x & x^2 \\
    1 & y & y^2 \\
    1 & z & z^2 \\
    \end{matrix}
$$
```
produces:
$$
    \begin{matrix}
    1 & x & x^2 \\
    1 & y & y^2 \\
    1 & z & z^2 \\
    \end{matrix}
$$
MathJax will adjust the sizes of the rows and columns so that everything fits.

output.content:
Use $$\begin{matrix}…\end{matrix}$$ In between the \begin and \end, put the matrix elements. End each matrix row with \\, and separate matrix elements with &. For example,

$$
    \begin{matrix}
    1 & x & x^2 \\
    1 & y & y^2 \\
    1 & z & z^2 \\
    \end{matrix}
$$

produces: 1xx21yy21zz2 \begin{matrix} 1 & x & x^2 \\ 1 & y & y^2 \\ 1 & z & z^2 \\ \end{matrix} 111​xyz​x2y2z2​ MathJax will adjust the sizes of the rows and columns so that everything fits.

input.source: To add brackets, either use `\left…\right` as in section 6 of the tutorial, or replace matrix with `pmatrix` $\begin{pmatrix}1&2\\3&4\\ \end{pmatrix}$, `bmatrix` $\begin{bmatrix}1&2\\3&4\\ \end{bmatrix}$, `Bmatrix` $\begin{Bmatrix}1&2\\3&4\\ \end{Bmatrix}$, `vmatrix` $\begin{vmatrix}1&2\\3&4\\ \end{vmatrix}$, `Vmatrix` $\begin{Vmatrix}1&2\\3&4\\ \end{Vmatrix}$.

output.content: To add brackets, either use \left…\right as in section 6 of the tutorial, or replace matrix with pmatrix (1234)\begin{pmatrix}1&2\\3&4\\ \end{pmatrix}(13​24​), bmatrix [1234]\begin{bmatrix}1&2\\3&4\\ \end{bmatrix}[13​24​], Bmatrix {1234}\begin{Bmatrix}1&2\\3&4\\ \end{Bmatrix}{13​24​}, vmatrix ∣1234∣\begin{vmatrix}1&2\\3&4\\ \end{vmatrix}∣∣∣∣∣​13​24​∣∣∣∣∣​, Vmatrix ∥1234∥\begin{Vmatrix}1&2\\3&4\\ \end{Vmatrix}∥∥∥∥∥​13​24​∥∥∥∥∥​.

input.source:
Use `\cdots` $\cdots$ `\ddots` $\ddots$ `vdots` $vdots$ when you want to omit some of the entries: 
$$ 
\begin{pmatrix}
 1 & a_1 & a_1^2 & \cdots & a_1^n \\
 1 & a_2 & a_2^2 & \cdots & a_2^n \\
 \vdots  & \vdots& \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
 1 & a_m & a_m^2 & \cdots & a_m^n    
\end{pmatrix}
$$

output.content: Use \cdots ⋯\cdots⋯ \ddots ⋱\ddots⋱ vdots vdotsvdotsvdots when you want to omit some of the entries: (1a1a12⋯a1n1a2a22⋯a2n⋮⋮⋮⋱⋮1amam2⋯amn) \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a_1 & a_1^2 & \cdots & a_1^n \\ 1 & a_2 & a_2^2 & \cdots & a_2^n \\ \vdots & \vdots& \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 1 & a_m & a_m^2 & \cdots & a_m^n \end{pmatrix} ⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​11⋮1​a1​a2​⋮am​​a12​a22​⋮am2​​⋯⋯⋱⋯​a1n​a2n​⋮amn​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​

input.source:
For horizontally "augmented" matrices, put parentheses or brackets around a suitably-formatted table; see arrays below for details. Here is an example:
$$
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
  1&2&3\\
  4&5&6
  \end{array}\right]
$$
is produced by:
```
$$ \left[
\begin{array}{cc|c}
  1&2&3\\
  4&5&6
\end{array}
\right] $$
```
The `cc|c` is the crucial part here; it says that there are three centered columns with a vertical bar between the second and third.

output.content:
For horizontally "augmented" matrices, put parentheses or brackets around a suitably-formatted table; see arrays below for details. Here is an example: [123456] \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1&2&3\\ 4&5&6 \end{array}\right] [14​25​36​] is produced by:

$$ \left[
\begin{array}{cc|c}
  1&2&3\\
  4&5&6
\end{array}
\right] $$

The cc|c is the crucial part here; it says that there are three centered columns with a vertical bar between the second and third.

input.source:
For vertically "augmented" matrices, use \hline. For example
$$
  \begin{pmatrix}
    a & b\\
    c & d\\
  \hline
    1 & 0\\
    0 & 1
  \end{pmatrix}
$$
is produced by
```
$$
  \begin{pmatrix}
    a & b\\
    c & d\\
  \hline
    1 & 0\\
    0 & 1
  \end{pmatrix}
$$
```

output.content:
For vertically "augmented" matrices, use \hline. For example (abcd1001) \begin{pmatrix} a & b\\ c & d\\ \hline 1 & 0\\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} ⎝⎜⎜⎜⎛​ac10​bd01​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎞​ is produced by

$$
  \begin{pmatrix}
    a & b\\
    c & d\\
  \hline
    1 & 0\\
    0 & 1
  \end{pmatrix}
$$

input.source: For small inline matrices use `\bigl(\begin{smallmatrix} ... \end{smallmatrix}\bigr)`, e.g. $\bigl( \begin{smallmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{smallmatrix} \bigr)$ is produced by: `$\bigl( \begin{smallmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{smallmatrix} \bigr)$`

output.content: For small inline matrices use \bigl(\begin{smallmatrix} ... \end{smallmatrix}\bigr), e.g. (abcd)\bigl( \begin{smallmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{smallmatrix} \bigr)(ac​bd​) is produced by: $\bigl( \begin{smallmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{smallmatrix} \bigr)$
